results.title: Goodbye war
results.creator_credit: Donna Dudinsky, Barbara Sears, Judith Merritt and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War”.
For centuries the international system of states has settled questions of power, territory, national pride and sovereignty with military force. At any given time there are about twenty wars being waged in the international neighbourhood, and in all of them, the people have a particular goal they want to achieve, a goal which they believe outweighs the cost of war. Dyer looks at a number of recent examples. He also examines the efforts of citizens’ peace movements in Europe, in the USA and in the Soviet Union. He suggests that we must find an alternative to war if the planet is to survive.

results.title: Keeping the old game alive
results.creator_credit: Douglas Kiefer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “War”.
Every autumn in central Europe, the combined forces of fifteen member countries of NATO meet to conduct their war games - the most elaborate dress rehersal for World War III. Dyer examines some of the technically sophisticated conventional weaponry used by modern armies and outlines the nightmarish effects of chemical weapons on unprotected civilians.

results.title: Deadly game of nations
results.creator_credit: Paul Cowan, Bill Brind, John Kramer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “War”.
All through history, wars have been linked to feelings of nationalism. There is hardly any country in the world that did not establish iself by means of wars. In this film Gwynne Dyer explors some of the reasons why pople, and governments acting on their behalf, feel the need to keep armies and fight wars. It focuses on Israel’s struggle for a secure place amongst the Arab nations of the Middle East, and on the so far unsuccessful attempts of the Palestinians to create a nation of their own.

results.title: Anybody's son will do
results.creator_credit: Paul Cowan, Bill Brind, John Kramer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War”.
Offers unusually frank insights into techniques that all armies use to motivate recruits. The film takes us to Parris Island Marine Recruit Training Depot in South Carolina, USA, to observe the rituals that will transform a motley group of eighteen year-olds into soldiers of the United States Marine Corps, unquestionably the roughest, toughest branch in the US military. It is a gripping study of what it takes to change ordinary civilians into the staple of wars, soldiers ready to kill, even to die for their country.

results.title: The road to total war
results.creator_credit: Barbara Sears and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “War”.
From Napoleon to Nagasaki, Gwynne Dyer charts how the major social, economic and technical developments of the last two hundred years have changed the methods and impact of modern warfare to lead us to the brink of total destruction. He guides the viewer through two centuries of world military history, recounting anecdotes and describing in vivid detail significant and sometimes little known events from past wars.
